Pros: The company fosters a collaborative and supportive work culture where every employee's contribution is valued. The level of teamwork I've witnessed here is commendable, promoting an environment where everyone can thrive. Moody's also offers excellent career growth opportunities. They invest in their employees, providing ample training and learning resources to ensure everyone has the tools to succeed. This commitment to professional development is evident in the number of internal promotions and the breadth of skills among the staff. In terms of diversity and inclusiveness, Moody's stands out. The company is committed to creating a workplace where diverse perspectives are valued and everyone feels included. This commitment is not just in words but is evident in their policies and practices. The recruitment process at Moody's is efficient and candidate-friendly. Communication is timely, feedback is constructive, and the overall candidate experience is positive. This reflects the company's respect for individuals and their time.
Cons: Overall, Moody's is an excellent place to work and grow professionally. It's a company that truly values its employees and is committed to fostering a positive and inclusive work environment.

Pros: It's a very employee friendly organisation
Cons: Work life balance is sometime a concern

Pros: A place to start in your career
Cons: Extreme workload - you are expected to consistently meet an unrealistic target and are made to feel that its your own fault if you can't meet it consistently. The blame culture is toxic and makes you scared of stepping out of line or challenging management. New systems were recently put in place, making the workload a lot more difficult to manage, but the target was not compensated for. This led to the whole team failing to keep up with the workload, and all the team left (there is a very high turnover of staff because workers are exploited). Finding a work/life balance is extremely difficult, as the increasing workload and lack of pay increases meant that finding a half an hour slot to take your lunch break was impossible. I was put on an improvement plan for not being able to meet the target and had my sick pay taken away from me despite having worked there for a year and a half and always meeting expectations. Also, you don't get any recognition for good performance, just a "pat on the back" email with a smiley face. Career progression is rare, as long time workers aren't valued. The pay is extremely low for the amount of stress, pressure, and high expectations the job comes with. Some teams aren't held as accountable as others (making a mistake while on my team wouldn't have been noticed on any other team). Suggestions in team meetings were never listened to. Management fails to recognise when their employees are struggling. A lot of the staff are passive aggressive and patronising. The company claims it values mental health, but punishes employees for having mental health issues by taking away their sick pay and scaring them into doing better by putting their job on the line. The exiting experience was also miserable and poorly handled, again, proving how little the management will value you as an employee. No bonuses apart from the occasional pizza party. Though some team members were nice, it felt like this was because we could relate to each other with how bad the company is. Felt like fighting an uphill battle against management, and always being told to "get over it". Your performance is solely based on who is checking your deal input. A subjective bias from some team members will result in you being errored accordingly, thus making error quality reports decline unfairly. The company does not value its clients, as recent changes made it so less deals would be added to the system for clients to access.

Review Title: Health of company under new CEO dives south
Pros:
- culture is inclusive and makes one feel that you are part of something big
 - people working in the firm are smart, hardworking, innovative and driven
- medical benefits are good
Cons:
- hire and fire culture corresponding with the myopic way of running business by the top management and the current CEO 
-noticeable disparity in the firm in top management where the leaders don’t have a solid pedigree and carry a certain narcissistic and self aggrandizing one fits all way of running business. The layoff mosaic is designed by these cadre of people 
-can’t trust them on face value as anything expressed can be retracted (the fact of paying lip service is very true) and it’s sad to see that there is a pattern of about face in this culture (wonder if it’s encouraged under the new CEO) and it’s no more the stable and respectable company where people marked a life time of a career
- most other type of benefits or employee privileges got retracted 
- no and absolutely no plan/resources committed to employee outings or socials

Review Title: Stay away from Controllership or COE roles
Pros: Recognizable company name to put on your resume. Stock purchase program and the stock is doing really well. Descent insurance.
Cons: High stress, low reward environment in Controllership/COE. Mediocre salaries. 80% of staff roles are located in lower cost areas, such as Costa Rica and India, where talent is scarce and workers who have the necessary skills to perform the work leave for better opportunities. Culture toxic as politics play a major role in it. DEI is a joke. Managers are overworked. The HQ is outdated and feels like a dungeon (unless you're on the top 3 floors). Unrealistic goals set by the CEO, the CFO and the Controller (2022).

Review Title:
What happens when the credit rating agencies have a oligopoly on credit markets? 

Find out below.
Pros:
This is a company that suits someone looking for 1). Sufficient work life balance, 2). Great benefits, & 3). Intellectually capable people 


However…  (read cons)
Cons:
What happens when 3 major credit agencies have captured the credit rating market? 

You get the following: 
- a culture of stagnation, where there is no need to push boundaries or trail-blaze. Instead, this job is almost like a pseudo government job. 

- as a result, this is not the place for a young ambitious professional. 


- due to 08/09, compliance might be the biggest spend. This a nightmare for employees who are interested in actual intellectual and financial analysis.  The company has been forced to over invest in compliance and IT security and has severely underinvested in software capabilities for their employees.  The CEO once said, “we are ten years behind in technology” and that couldn’t be more true. 

Ultimately, the question, will this ever change? No. 

This is because the CRAs have captured a market and must satisfy quality to regulators to continue doing business as normal. 

This is not a hard proposition.

Pros: Moody's value their customers. And the work culture
Cons: I think there is nothing right now.

Pros: - work-life balance - financial sector exposure
Cons: - personal development and career opportunities are lacking - no internal promotion process
